conclusion: Consider the layout of blocks and path of toy car based on collision and deflection physics.
Car A is moving from the right side towards the group of blocks.
First block likely to collide with is the blue block directly in its path.
Upon hitting the blue block, the car will likely be deflected.
Direction of deflection depends on angle and force of impact.
Given initial direction, car might be deflected slightly upwards or to the left.
After deflection, car might collide with nearby orange block or continue towards green block.
If deflected upwards, car might hit the orange block next.
If deflected left, car might hit the green block.
After second collision, car will likely lose more momentum.
Car may collide with one more block before stopping, depending on remaining energy.
Car will eventually stop near the last block it collides with.
Analysis assumes typical toy car physics with predictable deflections and energy loss.
Second collision: Likely orange block if deflected upwards, or green block if deflected left.
Final stop: Near the second block it collides with, either orange or green block.
